head.title: Political Briefing; A Money-Back Offer From an Incumbent

hedline.hl1: Political Briefing; A Money-Back Offer From an Incumbent

abstract.p: Comment on decision by former lifelong Democrat US Repr Virgil H Goode to run for re-election from Virginia's Fifth Congressional District as independent and to give Democrats who contributed to his $400,000 campaign war chest a refund (S)

How hard will it be to win re-election as an independent?

Democrats in Virginia's Fifth Congressional District were not especially surprised earlier this year when Representative Virgil H. Goode, a lifelong member of their party, announced he would seek re-election this fall as an independent and caucus with Republicans should he win. His votes on Capitol Hill had been trending Republican for some time.
How hard will it be to win re-election as an independent?

Probably not all that difficult. Both Democrats and Republicans in the district, in the south-central part of the state, tend to be strongly conservative, and in earlier elections Mr. Goode not only got the Democratic vote but also a lot of the Republican vote. What is more, the district, like Mr. Goode, has been trending Republican for some time.

So with no strong Democratic challenger in the offing -- and no Republican even running -- he seems well positioned to win again. But just to be safe, he tried last week to soften what Democratic opposition there is.
Any Democrat who gave him campaign money before he became an independent, he said, can mail in a request for a refund -- he has almost $400,000 in his war chest -- and it will be considered.
As of the weekend, only one request had come in, for $50, and the check was in the mail, with a note of thanks for past support.
